Metal–organic framework–derived CeO2 catalyst supported by carboxyl–functionalized MXene for oxidative coupling of benzyl alcohol with aniline Lei Zhuang Investigation Methodology Writing – original draft Mingyuan Jian Investigation Kecan Dou Methodology Deqiong Xie Investigation Gaomei Tu Methodology Weidong Zhu Project administration Fumin Zhang Conceptualization Project administration Supervision Writing – review & editing ⁎ Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials, Institute of Physical Chemistry, Zhejiang Normal University, Jinhua 321004, PR China Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials, Institute of Physical Chemistry Zhejiang Normal University Jinhua 321004 PR China Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials, Institute of Physical Chemistry, Zhejiang Normal University, Jinhua 321004, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Direct oxidative coupling of alcohols and amines is a highly sought–after method for imine synthesis, and non–precious metal catalysts have been identified as essential components for their efficient production. Here, we report a CeO2 catalyst that is supported by carboxyl–functionalized MXene (CFMX). The catalyst, referred to as CeO2–C@CFMX–T (where T is the pyrolysis temperature), was prepared by high–temperature pyrolysis of a Ce–based metal–organic framework (MOF) and MXene composite (MOF@MXene) in a nitrogen flow environment. The MOF@MXene composite was synthesized by directly assembling Ce–MOF on the outer surface of MXene, which was pre–functionalized with terminal carboxylated aryl diazonium salts. The developed CeO2–C@CFMX–873 exhibited outstanding catalytic behavior in the oxidative coupling of benzyl alcohol and aniline, without the need for any basic additives. The catalyst achieved high benzyl alcohol conversion (98.9 %), desirable imine selectivity (97.7 %), good recyclability (5 cycles), and broad substrate tolerance (22 examples) under mild conditions (353 K, air atmosphere). It was found that the CFMX support improved the dispersion of CeO2 nanoparticles and alleviated the problem of CeO2 aggregation during pyrolysis. The remarkable activity of CeO2–C@CFMX–873 was attributed to reversible Ce3+/Ce4+ redox pairs, abundant oxygen vacancies, and an appropriate number of acid–base sites. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords MXene Diazo salt modification MOF–derived nanocomposites Heterogeneous catalysis oxidative coupling Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Imines play a pivotal role as intermediates in the manufacturing of pesticides, dyes, pharmaceuticals, and fine chemicals. These compounds feature C=N bonds that serve as reactive electrophilic centers in diverse organic reactions [1–3]. Traditional approaches to imine formation frequently necessitate the utilization of costly noble metals like palladium and gold catalysts, which restrict their industrial applicability owing to their prohibitively high cost and limited storage capacity [4–6]. Recently, direct oxidative coupling of alcohols and amines has emerged as an environmentally friendly and cost–effective strategy for the synthesis of amines [7–13]. This method benefits from readily available and inexpensive alcohols, the utilization of air as an oxygen source, and the possibility of operating at low temperatures, all of which conform to the principles of sustainable chemistry [14]. This approach is potentially revolutionary in enhancing the efficiency and safety of imine production. Different catalysts, both homogeneous and heterogeneous, have been explored for this reaction [15–20]. In a study conducted by Kargar et al., a novel Cu–MOF catalyst was synthesized under ultrasonic irradiation [19]. The topological organization of the catalyst successfully prevented active site leaching by using covalently bound metal centers as nodes, resulting in a high oxidative cross–coupling activity. However, this process necessitates the use of tert–butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as an oxidizing agent, which is costly and leads to environmentally harmful byproducts. Furthermore, Wu et al. achieved superior alcohol conversion and imine selectivity in the oxidative coupling reaction of alcohols and amines without the need for a strong oxidant by developing a Zn–doped γ–Al2O3 supported Au nanoparticle catalyst [20]. Despite its high reactivity, this catalyst poses challenges due to its high cost, susceptibility to active component loss, and inability to be utilized on a large scale. Consequently, researchers aspire to establish catalyst systems based on non–precious metals. Tamura and colleagues found CeO2 to be a highly efficient catalyst for producing imines from aniline and benzyl alcohol in an air atmosphere, outperforming other metal oxide catalysts [21,22]. However, creating non–noble metal catalysts that exhibit excellent performance in oxidative coupling reactions is still a highly sought–after goal in catalysis research. MXenes, discovered in 2011, are 2D structural materials made up of transition metal carbides, nitrides, and carbon–nitrides with controllable phase structure and surface chemistry [23–25]. They show great potential in various fields including electrochemistry, catalysis, sensing, energy storage, and biomedicine [24–27]. Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), on the other hand, are excellent precursors for metal–oxide–based catalysts owing to their abundant metal nodes, precise framework, and customizable pore size [28–30]. However, direct pyrolysis of MOFs often leads to structural collapse and metal aggregation, which can obstruct the active sites of metal nanoparticles, thereby limiting their activity and recyclability [31,32]. Combining MXenes and MOFs through composites or derivatives holds potential for enhancing their performance and extending their applications. Recent studies have reported excellent H2 generation performance using a UiO–66–NH2 (Zr/Ti) photocatalyst tightly connected with MXene [33]. Similarly, efficient oxygen evolution reactions were achieved using Co3O4/Co2TiO4 catalysts derived from Ti3C2Tx/Co–MOF nanosheets [34]. However, MXene–supported metal catalysts derived from MOF@MXene composites for thermal catalysis applications remain largely unexplored. In this study, a Ce–MOF–801@CFMX composite was synthesized by a solvothermal method, where CFMX represents carboxyl functionalized MXene. Thereafter, a heterogeneous catalyst with CeO2 as active sites that were highly dispersed on CFMX was produced by high–temperature pyrolysis of Ce–MOF–801@CFMX. This catalyst was referred to as CeO2–C@CFMX–T (where T indicates pyrolysis temperature). Astonishingly, CeO2–C@CFMX–873 exhibited impressive catalytic activity in the oxidative coupling of benzyl alcohol with aniline. This result can be attributed to the effective chelation of Ce clusters by the carboxyl groups on CFMX, promoting a uniform and controlled growth of Ce–MOF–801 on the surface of CFMX. During annealing in an N2 environment, the Ce species in Ce–MOF–801 were converted into CeO2 nanoparticles, and uniformly stabilized on the outer surface of CFMX, thus generation of the CeO2–C@CFMX–873 catalyst. The copious presence of oxygen vacancies and reversible Ce3+/Ce4+ redox pairs, combined with appropriate acid–base sites, efficiently accelerated the performance of the oxidative coupling reaction over CeO2–C@CFMX–873 [35–37]. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of catalyst 2.1.1 Synthesis of Ce–MOF–801@CFMX In brief, a round bottom flask was used to accurately weigh 1.64 g (3 mmol) of (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6. Gradually, 6 mL of HCOOH, 35 mL of H2O, and 60 mg of CFMX were added to the flask while stirring the mixture at 600 rpm at room temperature for 1 hour. Following this, 1.74 g (15 mmol) of H2Fum was added to the solution, and the reaction was carried out in an oil bath at 333 K for 5 h. After the reaction, the mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature. The products were collected by centrifugation and then washed with water and ethanol to remove impurities before being dried for 12 h at 343 K. To synthesize Ce–MOF–801@MXene, the same procedure used for Ce–MOF–801@CFMX was implemented, with the exception that MXene was used as the support instead of CFMX. 2.1.2 Synthesis of CeO2–c@CFMX–t CeO2–C@CFMX catalyst were prepared by high–temperature carbonization treatment. The procedure involved introducing Ce–MOF–801@CFMX powder (0.8 g) into a quartz boat, which was then subjected to ramped heating (2 K/min) to a desired temperature in a tube furnace, all at 100 mL/min nitrogen flow. The temperature was maintained for 2 h and allowed to cool gradually to room temperature. The resulting black powder product was classified as CeO2–C@CFMX–T, where T was defined as the pyrolysis temperature of 573 K, 873 K and 1073 K. CeO2–C@MXene–873 was prepared using Ce–MOF–801@MXene as the precursor through a similar protocol to the one outlined above. For comprehensive information regarding the chemicals utilized and characterization of the catalyst, kindly refer to the Supporting Information (SI). 2.2 Catalytic performance test The catalytic activity of CeO2–C@CFMX–873 was evaluated for oxidative coupling of benzyl alcohol with aniline in a controlled environment. The experiment was performed in a 25 mL Schlenk tube with 20 mg of the catalyst added to a mixture of 0.3 mmol of benzyl alcohol, 0.45 mmol of aniline, and 2 mL of toluene in the presence of air. The reaction was initiated under intense stirring at 353 K in a thermostatic bath to ensure efficient condensation. Upon completion of the reaction, the catalyst was removed by centrifugation. Qualitative identification of the product was carried out using the Thermoscientific TRACE 1600/ISQ 7610/MS system. Quantitative evaluation of the conversion and selectivity of the resulting mixture was performed using a gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector and a HP–5 capillary column. To evaluate the durability of the CeO2–C@CFMX–873 catalyst, it was isolated from the reaction mixture and thoroughly rinsed with toluene and ethanol. Subsequently, it was dried at 393 K for a period of 12 h and subjected to reactivation in a tube furnace at 873 K before being utilized in the next cycle. 3 Results and discussion A distinctive carboxyl group–facilitated coordination strategy was employed to fabricate the Ce–MOF@CFMX composite, where CFMX represents carboxyl functionalized MXene [33]. This composite served as a precursor for generating a heterogeneous catalyst with CeO2 as the active site, which was highly dispersed on CFMX through high–temperature pyrolysis. As depicted in Scheme 1 , the process commenced with the exfoliation of the two–dimensional transition metal carbide Ti3AlC2 into Ti3C2 nanosheets via HF etchant. Subsequently, a certain amount of diazonium salt was added to the mixture of CFMX for improved synthesis of the MOF@CFMX composite. A controllable layer of Ce–MOF was then grown in situ on the outer surface of CFMX via a simple solvothermal process to form Ce–MOF–801@CFMX. Finally, the CeO2–C@CFMX catalyst was obtained by pyrolyzing Ce–MOF–801@CFMX under N2 flow environment. Fig. 1 depicts the X–ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of various catalysts. When compared to the simulated pattern of Ti3AlC2, the diffraction peak of the exfoliated sample at 39° disappeared, indicating the removal of the Al layer [38]. Additionally, the peaks corresponding to the planes (002) and (004) of Ti3AlC2 expanded and shifted to a lower degree, signifying the increase in lattice parameters through HF etching and the successful formation of the 2D Ti3C2 layer [33]. The presence of carboxyl groups on MXene did not alter its XRD pattern, validating that the modification of diazonium salt does not affect the MXene structure. Moreover, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectroscopy (Fig. S1) showed a band at 1700 cm–1, corresponding to the stretching vibration of C=O in CFMX, indicating a successful coupling of the carboxyl group to the MXene surface. Fig. 1b presents the XRD results of the synthesized Ce–MOF–801@CFMX, which is approximately identical to the simulated Ce–MOF model, demonstrating the successful synthesis of the Ce–MOF–801@CFMX precursor. The specific surface area of Ce–MOF–801@CFMX was calculated to be 149.1 m2/g (Fig. S2). Subsequently, the synthesized Ce–MOF–801@CFMX composite underwent hydrothermal treatment at 873 K in an N2 atmosphere, and the metal nodes were converted into CeO2 nanoparticles, resulting in the formation of a CeO2–C@CFMX–873 composite. As shown in Fig. 1c, the peaks at 26.5° and 44.3° correspond to the (002) and (100) crystal planes of graphite carbon, respectively. The peaks at 28.5° and 47.5° are attributed to the diffractions from the (111) and (220) planes of CeO2 (JCPDS No. 34–0394) [39,40]. The results indicated that the cerium oxide in CeO2–C@CFMX–873 possessed a cubic structure. The morphology and microstructure characteristics of the catalysts were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images. The etched 2D Ti3C2 exhibited an accordion–like multilayer structure (Fig. 2 a), coinciding with the prior reported result [27]. CFMX morphology remained unchanged after diazonium salt modification (Fig. 2b), indicating that the decorative process did not interfere with their structure, consistent with the XRD results. Ce–MOF was uniformly spread over the outer surface of CFMX, as seen in the SEM image of Ce–MOF–801@CFMX (Fig. 2c). The morphology of CeO2–C@CFMX–873 was essentially unaffected by high–temperature pyrolysis treatment (Fig. 2d). TEM and HRTEM images (Fig. 2e and f) showed HRTEM lattice distances of 0.32 and 0.21 nm, corresponding to the CeO2 plane (111) and CFMX plane (105), respectively. Using Scherrer formula, the calculated CeO2 crystal size was 5.2 nm for CeO2–C@CFMX–873 (Table S1). Furthermore, the catalyst showed a lattice spacing of 0.35 nm after annealing, indicative of the TiO2 plane (110), consistent with the XRD results of the support (Fig. S3). In addition, EDX mapping demonstrated a homogeneous distribution of C, O, and Ce species throughout the CeO2–C@CFMX–873 catalyst (Fig. S4). The CeO2–C@CFMX–873 catalyst displayed an IV isotherm and hysteresis loop and had a specific surface area of 121.6 m2/g (Fig. 3 a and Table S2). In the pore size distribution plot, CeO2–C@CFMX–873 exhibited a hierarchical porous structure with a large number of mesopores, macropores, and some micropores. The catalyst inherited the porous structure partially from the parent Ce–MOF–801@CFMX. Furthermore, the Raman spectra showed a large number of defects were generated during the carbonization with an intensity ratio of D–band to G–band of 0.86 (Fig. 3b). X–ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted to analyze the surface components and chemical states of CeO2–C@CFMX–873 (Table S3). As seen in Fig. 3c, the O 1 s photoelectron spectrum can be deconvoluted into three individual peaks at the binding energies of 530.2, 531.9, and 533.5 eV, indicating the presence of lattice oxygen (OLatt), surface active oxygen (OSur), and adsorbed oxygen (OAds), respectively [39]. The percentages of OLatt, OSur, and OAds were calculated from the high resolution XPS spectra of O 1 s and are shown in Table S4. Additionally, the XPS spectra of Ce 3d orbitals in Fig. 3d showed the peaks of Ce3+ at 884.5, and 903.1 eV and peaks of Ce4+ at 883.2, 888.4, 899.2, 907.1, and 917.2 eV, which indicated the presence of Ce4+/Ce3+ electron pairs in CeO2–C@CFMX–873 [41,42]. The presence of Ce3+ signified the absence of oxygen in the catalyst, which correlates with oxygen vacancies [35]. Under excitation at 325 nm, Raman experiments were conducted to gather information on oxygen vacancies in as–prepared catalysts. Fig. S5 shows that the peak at 454 cm–1 corresponds to the F2g Raman active vibration of fluorite CeO2 for CeO2–C@CFMX–873 [39,43]. Additionally, the D band observed within the 500–700 cm–1 range is attributed to oxygen vacancies within the catalyst, with peaks at 527 cm–1 (De) and 637 cm–1 (Di) [44,45]. The former is linked to the anchoring of CeO2 on the CFMX support, while the latter is believed to originate from intrinsic oxygen vacancies, a characteristic of Ce3+ in CeO2 [44]. Compared to the CeO2–C–873 catalyst, the peak at 580 cm–1 is redshifted to 637 cm–1, likely due to the interaction between cerium oxide nanoparticles and the CFMX support [46]. This further confirms successful compounding of CeO2 and CFMX support, in line with XRD results. Two additional samples were also prepared with varying pyrolysis temperatures, CeO2–C@CFMX–573 and CeO2–C@CFMX–1073, with respective characterizations illustrated in Figs. S6–S13. The results indicate that at higher pyrolysis temperatures, the catalyst surface roughness increases, and CeO2 crystal size also increases (Table S1). CeO2–C@CFMX–573 demonstrated the highest Ce3+ content and a relatively higher OSur/OLatt value than CeO2–C@CFMX–873 (Table S4). Following systematic characterization, the catalytic potential of CeO2–C@CFMX–873 was evaluated and compared with several control catalysts in the oxidative coupling of benzyl alcohol and aniline. Various reaction parameters, including reaction temperature, reaction substrate molar ratio, solvent, and catalyst dosage, were optimized to determine optimal conditions for achieving high imine yield and selectivity. The results are presented in Table S5. To examine the impact of different solvents on catalyst performance, various solvents, such as H2O, methanol, acetonitrile, and toluene, were screened. Among them, toluene showed the best activity, with a substrate conversion of 98.9 % and a desirable imine selectivity of 97.7 %. Therefore, toluene was chosen as the optimal solvent. The influence of the molar ratio of the substrate was also assessed. When the molar ratio of benzyl alcohol to aniline was changed from 1:1.5 to 1:2, imine selectivity decreased significantly. In addition, a decrease in catalytic activity was observed when the molar ratio was reduced to 1:1. In comparison, the highest imine yield and selectivity were achieved at a molar ratio of 1:1.5. The impact of the reaction temperature was also investigated. Increasing the temperature from 313 to 353 K resulted in a substantial increase in the conversion of benzyl alcohol from 56 to 98.9 %. Therefore, temperature rise has been identified as a critical factor in achieving high–yield imines. The optimum reaction temperature was determined at 353 K. Furthermore, the dependence of the yield of imine on the catalyst dosage was studied over CeO2–C@CFMX–873. Increasing the catalyst dosage from 10 to 20 mg, although the selectivity did not change significantly, the conversion increased from 71.0 to 98.9 %. Accordingly, the optimal catalyst quantity was determined to be 20 mg. In addition, the oxidative coupling process could be smoothly executed without solvents, attaining a 60 % yield of imine by prolonging the reaction time to 40 h. The catalytic activity of various catalysts in the oxidative coupling of benzyl alcohol and aniline was compared under optimized reaction conditions, as shown in Table 1 . No imine formation was observed when no catalyst was used or CFMX was the only catalyst used (entries 1 and 2). Likewise, the precursor Ce–MOF–801@CFMX did not exhibit catalytic activity (entry 3), suggesting that the active CeO2 sites were inevitable for the reaction. In sharp contrast, CeO2–C@CFMX–873 exhibited the highest catalytic activity, achieving benzyl alcohol conversion of 98.9 and 97.7 % selectivity for the target imine, which was much superior to pyrolyzed analogs at other temperatures (entries 4–6). By inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP–AES) analysis, the Ce content in CeO2–C@CFMX–873 was determined to be 24.9 % (Table S2). Notably, CeO2–C–873 without CFMX support (the related characterizations are available in Figs. S14–S17) resulted in a low conversion of only 37.2 % (entry 7), and commercial CeO2 (calcined at 873 K for 2 h) exhibited poor catalytic activity under the same reaction conditions (entry 8); furthermore, CeO2–C@MXene–873, with unfunctionalized MXene as support, showed inferior catalytic activity compared to CeO2–C@CFMX–873 (entry 9). To further demonstrate CeO2–C@CFMX–873′s outstanding catalytic activity, benzyl alcohol conversion as a function of reaction time was monitored and compared with CeO2–C–873 (Fig. 4 a). The results clearly demonstrate that CeO2–C@CFMX–873 exhibited significantly higher catalytic activity than CeO2–C–873. This can be partially attributed to the CFMX support, which improves the dispersion of active CeO2 nanoparticles, enhances contact between reactants, and increases access to active sites for heterogeneous catalysis. To evaluate the stability of CeO2–C@CFMX–873 as a heterogeneous catalyst in the oxidative coupling process, a hot filtration experiment was carried out after four hours of reaction (Fig. 4a). The catalyst was immediately separated from the reaction system when benzyl alcohol conversion reached 69.0 %. The solution without the solid catalyst was then allowed to react for another 13 h under the same conditions, during which no increase in benzyl alcohol conversion was observed. This demonstrated that CeO2–C@CFMX–873 possessed excellent stability during the oxidation process. Additionally, the reusability of CeO2–C@CFMX–873 was tested. After each cycle, the CeO2–C@CFMX–873 catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by filtration. Subsequently, it was reactivated at 873 K for 2 h and employed in the next cycle. It was found that catalytic activity and selectivity did not significantly change during five recycling cycles (Fig. 4b), highlighting the catalyst's excellent recyclability. However, it is noteworthy that the conversion of benzyl alcohol over the recovered catalyst, without any activation treatment, exhibited a significant decrease from 98.9 to 87.9 % after a single cycle. This phenomenon can be attributed to the residual presence of reactants on the catalyst, which hinders access to the catalytically active sites [18]. To further verify the high stability of CeO2–C@CFMX–873, the recovered catalyst was characterized by XRD, N2 adsorption isotherms, and TEM (Fig. S18). The crystal structure, specific surface area, and particle size of CeO2 in the recovered catalyst did not change significantly compared to the fresh catalyst. These performance tests and characterization results effectively confirm the excellent reusability and stability of CeO2–C@CFMX–873. Previous studies indicated that achieving the optimal balance of acidity and basicity in a catalyst was a crucial factor in enhancing oxidative coupling performance [40–42]. To confirm this conjecture, we conducted NH3–TPD and CO2–TPD analysis to investigate the acidity and basicity of the catalyst. The molecularly adsorbed CO2 at lower temperatures suggested weak interaction between CO2 and the catalyst, while stronger interactions were observed at higher temperatures [40]. As shown in Fig. 5 a, CeO2–C@CFMX–873 presented several CO2 desorption peaks, corresponding to weak and medium base sites between 323 and 423 K and 473–773 K, respectively. In contrast, CeO2–C–873 lacking MXene as the support produced only weak CO2 desorption peak at 323–423 K. This suggests that CeO2–C@CFMX–873 possesses more abundant basic sites than CeO2–C–873, which is anticipated to promote the conversion of benzyl alcohol in the oxidative coupling reaction [40]. Regarding NH3–TPD curve of CeO2–C@CFMX–873 (Fig. 5b), they could be identified into two distinct peaks at 373–473 K and 473–700 K, which can be attributed to weak and moderate acidic sites, respectively. In contrast, CeO2–C–873 displayed no ammonia desorption peaks between 373 and 700 K. These results indicate that CeO2–C@CFMX–873 catalyst has significantly higher number of moderately Lewis acid sites than CeO2–C–873, apparently originating from the presence of CFMX support [36]. Cao et al. have reported that surface acid sites of catalysts significantly contributed to the rate of condensation reactions of aldehydes and amines [42]. Based on these results, we concluded that loading CeO2 onto CFMX altered the surface acid/base properties, generating more intermediate base sites than pure CeO2, which facilitates the oxidation of alcohol to benzaldehyde. In addition, the presence of weak acid sites in CeO2–C@CFMX–873 facilitated the adsorption and activation of substrate aniline, making it more reactive with benzaldehyde. These findings provide critical insights into the superior performance of CeO2–C@CFMX–873 catalyst. Under optimized reaction conditions, the catalytic efficiency of CeO2–C@CFMX–873 for oxidative coupling various alcohols and amines to form imines was investigated. The results are presented in Table 2 . This catalyst exhibited exceptional activity and versatility in initiating substituted benzyl alcohols, including those with both electron–donating (–CH3 and –OCH3) and electron–withdrawing (–Br, –Cl, –F, –NO2) substituents, to yield high imine yields (entries 1–7). The reactivity levels of benzyl alcohol derivatives with different substituent positions followed a para–position > meta–position > ortho–position trend (entries 2, 8, 9). The difference in reactivity can be attributed to the spatial effects of reactant molecules, whereby a large steric barrier prevented the reaction. Significantly, the CeO2–C@CFMX–873 catalyst also effectively catalyzed the oxidative coupling of benzyl alcohol with diverse aniline derivatives, yielding higher imine yields (entries 12–19). Furthermore, CeO2–C@CFMX–873 was employed in the oxidative coupling reactions involving furan, pyridine, thiophene–substituted alcohols, and aniline (entries 20–22), but was found to be less efficient compared to the reaction between benzyl alcohols and aniline. These catalytic experiments confirm CeO2–C@CFMX–873 as a reliable catalyst for synthesizing imines via various oxidative coupling reactions. To gain clarity on the dissociation mechanism of the C–H bond at the benzylic carbon in benzyl alcohols, the impact of substituent groups on the reaction rate was examined in the context of imine formation using CeO2–C@CFMX–873. Various p–substituted benzyl alcohols, including p–Cl, p–NO2, p–H, p–CH3, and p–OCH3 benzyl alcohols, were investigated. Fig. 6 illustrates the relationship between log(k X/ k H) and the Hammett parameter (σ) in the imine formation process from benzyl alcohols and aniline with CeO2–C@CFMX–873. The slope (ρ) of –0.27 derived from the Hammett parameter (σ) suggests a possibility of a positively charged intermediate generated during the oxidative coupling process [47,48]. Based on the experimental results presented above, as well as the current literature results, we propose a potential mechanism for the oxidative coupling of alcohol and amine (Scheme 2 ) [22,42,49]. Initially, the alcohol dissociates and adsorbs onto the ceria, leading to the formation of alcohol oxides and protons. The lattice oxygen on ceria then oxidizes benzyl alcohol to aldehyde through oxidative dehydrogenation, which reduces Ce4+ to Ce3+. This step is critical to determining the reaction rate. The nucleophilic reaction between the aldehyde and amine adsorbate produces a propargyl alcohol amine adsorbate, which subsequently undergoes dehydration to form the corresponding imine and H2O. Finally, Ce3+ is oxidized back to Ce4+ by O2 in the air to regenerate the cerium oxide catalyst. In the CeO2–C@CFMX–873 catalyst, the presence of base sites promotes the oxidation of alcohols to benzaldehyde, while the weak acid sites result in a weak interaction between the catalyst surface and aniline. This ultimately enhances the conversion of benzyl alcohol and ensures the desired imine selectivity. It is worth noting that the imine condensation process is an equilibrium reaction, which is affected by pH and water content. Low pH values promote the reaction while the presence of water inhibits it [50]. 4 Conclusions In summary, we used diazonium salt modification on etched MXene material to create a CFMX support. This support served as a platform for the incorporation of Ce–MOF–801 via a hydrothermal process, resulting in the creation of a Ce–MOF–801@CFMX composite. Subsequently, high–temperature pyrolysis was utilized to obtain CeO2–C@CFMX–873. This catalyst demonstrated high catalytic activity (≥ 98 %) and chemoselectivity (≥ 97.7 %) in the oxidative coupling of benzyl alcohol and aniline. The impressive performance of the CeO2–C@CFMX–873 catalyst is a result of the unique synergistic effect between the CFMX support and CeO2, which yields a high level of dispersion of CeO2 nanoparticles on the support. Furthermore, a significant number of acidic and basic sites, a high concentration of oxygen vacancies, and the existence of surface Ce3+ defect sites have produced the catalyst with superior oxidation capability. As a result, our research underscores the potential applications of CeO2–C@CFMX–873 catalyst in several industrial scenarios. coredata.dc:description: Direct oxidative coupling of alcohols and amines is a highly sought–after method for imine synthesis, and non–precious metal catalysts have been identified as essential components for their efficient production. Here, we report a CeO2 catalyst that is supported by carboxyl–functionalized MXene (CFMX). The catalyst, referred to as CeO2–C@CFMX–T (where T is the pyrolysis temperature), was prepared by high–temperature pyrolysis of a Ce–based metal–organic framework (MOF) and MXene composite (MOF@MXene) in a nitrogen flow environment. The MOF@MXene composite was synthesized by directly assembling Ce–MOF on the outer surface of MXene, which was pre–functionalized with terminal carboxylated aryl diazonium salts. The developed CeO2–C@CFMX–873 exhibited outstanding catalytic behavior in the oxidative coupling of benzyl alcohol and aniline, without the need for any basic additives. The catalyst achieved high benzyl alcohol conversion (98.9 %), desirable imine selectivity (97.7 %), good recyclability (5 cycles), and broad substrate tolerance (22 examples) under mild conditions (353 K, air atmosphere). It was found that the CFMX support improved the dispersion of CeO2 nanoparticles and alleviated the problem of CeO2 aggregation during pyrolysis. The remarkable activity of CeO2–C@CFMX–873 was attributed to reversible Ce3+/Ce4+ redox pairs, abundant oxygen vacancies, and an appropriate number of acid–base sites.
coredata.dc:title: Metal–organic framework–derived CeO2 catalyst supported by carboxyl–functionalized MXene for oxidative coupling of benzyl alcohol with aniline
